title.rendered: Pepperstone Responds to Brazilian Regulator Warning

content.rendered:
The Australian and UK regulated broker, Pepperstone Group has recently come under scrutiny from Brazilian regulators regarding the onboarding of Brazilian residents as clients in the broker’s affiliated European entity. Specifically, Brazil’s Securities and Exchange Commission (CVM) posted an alert warning the public that Pepperstone was operating in Brazil illegally, having no authorization or license to do so.

In turn, Pepperstone Group provided feedback to our colleagues at Finance Magnates, indicating that “Pepperstone is not licensed in Brazil and does not purport to be. While we provide language support for Portuguese speakers, wherever they are located, we do not conduct business activities in Brazil nor do we actively market our products to or specifically target Brazilian residents.”

And furthermore that: “While we are comfortable that our practices to date regarding Brazilian clients have not in fact breached local rules and regulations, we will be making contact directly with CVM in Brazil to better understand their concerns on what may have triggered this.”

As such, Pepperstone has found itself in a position that has been experienced by other brokers in the past – being sanctioned in a particular way by a regulator due to the fact that residents of particular countries are actively pursuing to open a trading account on their own accord. While FX and derivatives can only be traded by companies that have been authorized by the regulator in Brazil, there is no civil law prohibiting Brazilians from opening trading accounts at overseas companies for the purpose of trading FX and derivatives. This is similar to a situation faced by brokers who provide trading and support services in the Russian language, which are popular with Russian residents, who are meant to be trading only with firms licensed by the Central Bank of Russia (CBR).
